answers.answer: Hi Jimmy....Congrats on your new baby!  Jimmy, is your new kitten eating wet food?  If not, I would encourage ALL wet food.  Cats naturally don't drink much water, they mainly get it within their diet, so you want to start off your new kitty with some good grain free wet food.  The grain free will be helpful in the future should your kitten become intolerant to grains, you'll have nipped this problem in the bud at the get go.Cats cannot get too much water, so what I would suggest (and also what I do with Jade) is add just the tiniest amt of water to the bottom of the bowl of wet food with each feeding.Can't wait to see new pic!!!!
Hi jade yes she is new ! I just got her . You remember my cat of 16 years died a few months ago . Ill post a pic for you ! She is a doll !

Hi Jade, I saw your post about the water, and our cat who is now 3 drinks water aLOT.  I mentioned it to the vet and he didn't seem concerned.  We make sure she has water available at all times, but should we be monitoring her intake?Thanks,Sandy ♦

it depend on how much you mean by alot??? do you think its EXCESSIVE?does she also pee alot? again do you think its excessive? like more than 2-3x per day?If you think its excessive than I would insist on a blood sugar test, this can be a sign of diabetes...

Hi Sandy...Has your cat always been a big water drinker?  Is she fed dry food or wet?  If dry, then her water intake would make sense...and is a good thing!  However, if you're feeding all wet food, then I would be concerned.  When Jade first came to us, she was a HUGE water drinker.  So much so, I thought for sure she had diabetes, but all it was, was the nothing but dry food by her previous owners.  When we took over her care (and before I found MH & this forum), we fed dry in the morning, then a can of wet at night, but still, she drank a ton of water...until I went with ALL wet food.  Now, I never see her drinking, even though I have water cups placed in several areas both outside and in.Sandy, how is the litter box looking?  Very wet?  If not, your girl is probably fine, but if I were you, I would have her checked for diabetes just to be on the safe side.

Yes, she's always been a big water drinker, even as a kitten.   And we do feed her dry food - she seems to really like it.  She doesn't necessarily drink alot at any one time;  we also keep a small bowl upstairs and one downstairs, and when she walks past the bowl, she stops for a few sips.Since I change out her water bowls, my husband gets litter box duty.  If I had to guess, I'd say she uses it 2 or 3 times a day, but I'll check with my husband.  He usually cleans it every night.I've read on another cat forum that some would never consider feeding their cat dry food, but our vet indicated that as long as it's a decent brand and not "junk" kitty food, it's fine.  I was relieved, because she seems to prefer dry over wet.    Other than excessive drinking, what are some signs of diabetes in cats?Thanks!Sandy ♦

hi...I wouldnt be concerned if she's peeing only the 2-3x per day esp since she is eating dry food like Jade said this will make kitty's more thirsty just b/c the food is so dehydrated. I will send you a site, I don't agree with your Vet at all abt ok to feed dry food.read the following site..and what this very knowledgeable Vet has to say abt dry food diets and all the health problems associated with it..you can also click on the right hand side under FELINE HEALTH there is the heading DIABETES and you can read up on that too.p.s. you don't have to go the route of raw diets as this Vet recommends, she does say that any canned food is much better than even the 'best' dry food..http://www.catinfo.org/

Thanks opus, I'll check it out.  The general concensus at the cat forum I was referring to earlier was that raw was pretty much the way to go.  Wet food was 2nd and dry was 3rd.   Problem is, our cat doesn't like wet food.  We've tried several different brands and she'll sniff at it, take a bite or 2 and then leave it.   And this is when she hasn't eaten all day.  When we give her dry, she loves it.  Or seems to - she at least eats it.   I guess we can try incorporating some wet into her dry food - but we've done that before without success.  Anywho, I'll check out the link and see what they say.Thanks for the response.Sandy

oh that is all quite familiar and common....giving a cat dry food is like us eating junk food all day and than being given vegetables..lol.I too went thru all this, I had 2 kibble heads here too before illnesses made it necessary to do the switch. its possible but takes time and patience...they won't switch overnight. the site I gave you also has many ideas on how to 'transition' into wet from dry....check out the links on the right hand side of her article..go slow add a small amount at a time to the dry...good luck♥
